text: [Music]
greetings my name is Matt words and I'm
here at the alias' headquarters in
Seattle with an exciting announcement
for application developers and DevOps
engineers we're pleased to announce the
general availability of AWS x-ray x-ray
helps developers analyze and debug
applications using distributed tracing
using x-ray you can pinpoint and
understand the root causes of issues
errors and performance bottlenecks in
addition we're also excited to announce
the preview of x-ray support for AWS
lambda providing service application
developers a new way to analyze the
performance of their lambda functions
traditional debugging methods don't work
well for production applications or
applications built using a
service-oriented or micro-services
architecture which there are multiple
independent components run on services
such as ec2 the ec2 container service
DynamoDB and elastic beanstalk with
x-ray you can easily identify which part
of your application is causing the issue
and see detailed information about
requests being made to the app such as
their latency HTTP response status
number of errors and downstream calls to
other services x-ray provides a visual
map showing your applications
architecture which helps you quickly see
where the errors are occurring x-ray
makes it easy to analyze apps running on
ec2 or on containers by the ec2
container service with the preview of
lambda support you can now see how long
lambda takes to execute your code from
the time and event sources triggered to
n-lambda begins to actually execute your
code and finally when the function
terminates you can now even see
downstream service calls being made
within your function or the time it
takes to execute the code above your
functions handler you can get started
with x-ray it's simple and requires
minimal setup thanks a lot
[Music]
